abstract: The government’s strategy of relying on lower-level employees to investigate Steven A. Cohen is not without its challenges. | Jack Ma, the founder of Alibaba, is giving up his C.E.O. title but staying on as executive chairman. | Shares of Dell rose on Monday after a report that the company was in talks over a potential buyout. | Thomas Weisel, a legendary banker behind Yahoo’s public offering, has been thrust in the spotlight for backing Lance Armstrong.
snippet: The government’s strategy of relying on lower-level employees to investigate Steven A. Cohen is not without its challenges. | Jack Ma, the founder of Alibaba, is giving up his C.E.O. title but staying on as executive chairman. | Shares of Dell ros...
lead_paragraph: IN PURSUIT OF COHEN, ONE DEAD END  |  The government’s investigation of suspicious trading at SAC Capital Advisors has relied on lower-level employees who are mined for information about the firm’s boss, Steven A. Cohen. But the investigation of Jonathan Hollander, a former SAC employee who cooperated with prosecutors, shows the challenges of using that strategy, DealBook’s Peter Lattman and Ben Protess report.

headline.main: In Pursuit of Cohen, One Dead End
